abstract.p: Survey by Progressive, auto insurance company, reveals that about three-quarters of people who use their cell phones while driving make social, not business, calls (S)

block.p: Just who are people talking to when they use their cell phones on the road? Well, probably not their bosses or secretaries.

About three-quarters of people who use their cell phones while driving alone in their cars called friends or relatives, not co-workers, according to Progressive, the auto insurance company based in Mayfield Village, Ohio. It asked the question in a survey on its Web site late last year. About 840 people responded, and the results were released last week.
Just who are people talking to when they use their cell phones on the road? Well, probably not their bosses or secretaries.

About three-quarters of people who use their cell phones while driving alone in their cars called friends or relatives, not co-workers, according to Progressive, the auto insurance company based in Mayfield Village, Ohio. It asked the question in a survey on its Web site late last year. About 840 people responded, and the results were released last week.

In fact, about one-third of those who used their cell phones while driving alone said they had not made a work-related call in the previous six months, although about half made their calls while driving to or from work, the company found.
So who are these traveling cell phone users? Sixty-one percent were men, and 71 percent were between the ages of 18 and 34. Most drove midsize cars.
About half said they used their cell phones while driving mainly because it was the most convenient time for them to be on the phone.
